title: 113_hr4965
content: The "Pre-K for USA Act" is cited as the short title. Grants for improving early childhood care and education are provided under the Act through amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The "Pre-K for USA Act" authorizes competitive grants for qualified entities to develop high-quality preschool programs for preschool-aged children. Applications must be submitted to the Secretaries for consideration. Up to 3% of funds can be used for technical assistance and evaluation purposes. The Secretaries are required to submit reports to Congress on the activities related to awarding grants for high-quality preschool programs, including progress of qualified entities and use of grants for program expansion. The curr_chunk discusses the costs and barriers to expanding high-quality preschool programs, including building and renovating facilities. It defines a high-quality preschool program as one with evidence-based structural elements and staff qualifications. The curr_chunk outlines key requirements for high-quality preschool programs, including staff qualifications, staff-child ratio, class size, full-day program, inclusion of children with disabilities, and developmentally appropriate curricula aligned with state standards. The curr_chunk outlines requirements for high-quality preschool programs, including individualized accommodations, staff salaries comparable to K-12 teachers, program evaluation, comprehensive services, and health and safety standards. Qualified entity refers to a local educational or government agency, and Secretaries refers to the Secretary of Education and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The curr_chunk authorizes appropriations for the implementation of high-quality preschool programs from 2015 to 2024. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include grants for improving early childhood care and education.
